Award.AwardTitle: U.S.-India Planning Visit: Collaborative Research on Algorithms for Digital Microfluidic Biochips
Award.AbstractNarration:
104108
Krishnendu Chakrabarty

This award supports the U.S.-India Planning Visit: Collaborative Research on Algorithms for Digital Microfluidic Biochips. Professors K. Chakrabarty, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Duke University and Bhargab Bhattacharya, Advanced Computing and Microelectronics, Indian Statistical Institute (ISI), Kolkata, India intend to identify collaborative research directions on algorithms for the optimization of digital microfluidic biochips.

The initial focus will be on dilution and mixing of liquids on a biochip. Prof. Chakrabarty from Duke University brings to this collaboration his expertise on digital microfluidics and chip design. Prof. Bhattacharya is an expert on design and analysis of algorithms. The proposed collaboration will explore new algorithms and optimization techniques for making digital microfluidic biochips more efficient and practical for healthcare applications.

The planning visit will lead to a longer-term collaborative research proposal to be submitted to the National Science Foundation (NSF) and to the Department of Science and Technology (DST) in India for consideration under the NSF-DST Joint Program. In the follow-up research proposal, t, PhD students from both countries will work in close collaboration. In addition to receiving
interdisciplinary education and training in different aspects of biochip design, US students will gain professional experience and cultural exposure beyond the nation?s borders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This seed grant from NSF was intended to develop a collaboration with researchers in India and plan follow-up proposal to NSF and DST-India. The collaboration was very successful in terms of research results and publications. A jpint proposal t NSF and DST could not be submitted because there was no timely solicitation from DST on US-India collaborative projects. However, an NSF award was received in a related topic (cyberphysical systems for digital microfluidics).

The research was focused on new algorithms for on-chip sample dilution and mixing for sample preparation ion biochemical assays. The underlying on-chip (hardware) platform was digital microfluidics. Several new techniques were  developed to minimize the number of mixing steps, usage of samples and reagents, and minimize wastage. Chip layout methods  were also been developed. The research findings were disseminated in two journal articles and five conference papers.

Sample preparation plays an important role in diagnostics. In 2007, the worldwide market for in vitro diagnostics was estimated at $38 billion, and 1.5 billion diagnostic tests per year worldwide has been predicted for malaria alone. In the past decade, the average number of tests required for molecular analysis in biotechnology has risen to 15 billion tests per year. Moreover, 90% of the cost and 95% of the analysis time is associated with sample collection, transportation, and preparation. 

The results generated by this research project are therefore expected to significantly reduce the cost of clinical diagnostics for healthcare applications.
